data.title: Let's see your BC Rich's past and present
data.meta_description:
Well, I am really missing my BC Rich guitars.  As an homage I wish to share what I had.  I invite you all to do so as well.  

1981 USA BC Rich Bich-6...

Joined

Messages

19,650

Reaction score

21,313

Mar 13, 2013

#1

Well, I am really missing my BC Rich guitars. As an homage I wish to share what I had. I invite you all to do so as well.

1981 USA BC Rich Bich-6

1985 NJ Series BC Rich ST-III

1985 NJ Series BC Rich Warlock

1984 NJ Series BC Rich ST-III

1985 NJ Series BC Rich Mockingbird

BC Rich Mockingbird Calibre (prototype)

With the exception of the Warlock and red ST-III, they were all neck-thru. Damn, they were great guitars. I really, really miss the Bich-6, the Mockingbird Calibre and the yellow ST-III. They were magnificent guitars in every way. Oh well, I was honored to have once owned and played them.

This site may earn a commission from merchant links like Ebay, Amazon, and others.

#7

One day, when I have money again, I'm so getting a Mockingbird, short-horn, birdseye maple, bells & whistle guitar. It's actually my, MUST HAVE, guitar.

I love my current Les Paul, best LP I ever had, but quality wise BCR blows Gibson away. Well the 80's one. Actually, my Mockingbird Calibre was a pretty special guitar as well. I would have kept that over my LP quality wise, but man I love an LP growl!

no pictures but I started playing B.C.Rich in 1979 .still have my first one ..a seagull supreme, had 2 bitches one natural koa and one gunmetal metallic, and a eagle supreme with a strat tail pc. [didn't workout , peghead design]there were/are great guitars . my wife and I used to go to the ''factory'' and hang with neal moser . built him a nice flintlock rifle for that koa bitch. good days , great guitars .

#14

I still have this one, and they will pry it from my cold dead hands! Tone like no other axe I've ever played. I don't know how to identify it exactly because there is no paper trail (BC Rich warehouse fire). What I do know, several experts have said it is genuine, but BC Rich never offered all of these options together, yet the guitar shows no signs of modification.

Details:

1987 BC Rich USA ST III

24-fret neck-thru

Kahler 2300 bridge

EMG-60 in the rhythm position and EMG-81 in the lead position.

Wait.... Your friend is Dick Wagner? Huwhaaaaat? I think we need to hear more about this. Saying your friends with one of the most unsung guitar heros ever, that helped shape the sound of rock isn't something you just causally throw out there.

Is Dick the reason Joe Perry played BCR or is it the other way around?
